Title:
Molecular phylogenetics and sequence analysis of two
cave-dwelling Dugesia species from Southeast Asia (Platyhelminthes:
Tricladida: Dugesiidae)
Keywords: Dugesia, paleogeography, Batu Caves, Tham Nen Noi
Abstract:
The low dispersal ability of planarian flatworms from the
speciose genus Dugesia Girard, 1850, and their confinement to contiguous
water bodies, make them useful paleogeographical indicators. Thus it was
a surprise for Dugesia biogeographical study when twenty years ago,
Dugesia ryukyuensis Kawakatsu, 1976, which is endemic to the Ryukyu
Islands in Japan, was found to be karyologically and phenotypically
closer to Dugesia batuensis Ball, 1970 from Malaysia, rather than to
Dugesia japonica Ichikawa & Kawakatsu, 1964, which shares its
geographical range in the Japanese Islands. Elevating this puzzling
conundrum to the level of a hypothesis in the paleogeographical study of
Southeast Asia requires corroborating evidence from molecular
phylogenetics. We obtained hitherto unavailable nucleotide sequence data
from cytochrome oxidase I (COI), internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS-1)
and 28S rDNA sequences of two Southeast Asian Dugesia species: D.
batuensis from Batu Caves of Malaysia, and Dugesia deharvengi Kawakatsu
& Mitchell, 1989 from Tham Nen Noi cave in Chumpae Province of
Thailand. Sequence analysis revealed a novel 25bp duplication in ITS-1
of D. deharvengi. Using homologous sequences from Dugesia species
present in GenBank, we also discovered a molecular synapomorphy that
characterises the clade consisting of D. batuensis, D. ryukyuensis, D.
deharvengi, and D. notogaea Sluys & Kawakatsu, 1998 from Australia.
Morever, the maximum likelihood phylogeny based on ITS-1 revealed that
D. japonica may be basal to the Oriental-Australasia clade, and that D.
batuensis shares a most recent common ancestor with D. ryukyuensis,
rather than with D. deharvengi. The present results indicate that a
molecular phylogenetics programme to complement Dugesia biogeographical
study in Southeast Asia can be potentially useful for improving current
understanding of the geological history of this region.
